metadata.title: Developmental Language Impairment  Upper Elementary School-Aged Children and Adolescents
synonyms: language impairment, developmental: upper elementary school-aged  children and adolescents
developmental language disorder: upper elementary school-aged  children and adolescents
anatomical location body part affected: Developmental language impairment is defined by the absence of other discernible neurological diagnoses in the presence of language difficulties. One study using MRI reported that there was a higher incidence of brain morphological abnormalities in children with developmental LI; however, not all children with developmental LI manifested abnormalities, and the authors noted that there is great heterogeneity in this population(1)
description: The description of language disorder/impairment differs with the specific term used and varying diagnostic criteria:

Specific language impairment (SLI; sometimes called primary language impairment [PLI]) has been described as delayed or disordered language development “in the absence of general cognitive deficits, hearing impairments, psychiatric problems, or frank neurological damage”(2)

Expressive language disorder signifies an impairment in language production rather than language comprehension, and is a term recognized by the ICD-10;  however, the existence of an expressive disorder in the absence of a receptive language disorder has been questioned by experts(3)

Language impairment/disorder, or language learning disorder, has been used in multiple studies to describe children who score below the average range on language tests and who have normal nonverbal intelligence quotient (IQ) as well as those who score in the mild intellectual disability range or whose exact IQ score is unknown.(4) The rationale for including children who have mild intellectual disability is based on evidence that these children perform similarly in language therapy to those who score within the normal range and that many children are identified as having a language impairment without receiving IQ testing(5)

This summary will employ this broader definition, using the term language impairment (LI) to refer to children who have a language disorder from a very young age as a primary disability and who do not necessarily show a significant discrepancy between language ability and nonverbal IQ. For information on language disorders as a result of secondary disabilities, see the Clinical Reviews on hearing loss, vision loss, intellectual disability, childhood aphasia, cerebral palsy, and traumatic brain injury. A child or adolescent with LI may have difficulty with one or more aspects of language, including comprehension and expression of complex oral and written syntax, semantics, or  pragmatics and often presents with problems in attention, speech perception, working memory, and phonological awareness(4)

ICD-10 codes.F80.2: mixed receptive-expressive language disorder (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for procedure will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: A child or adolescent with LI is likely to have a history of delayed language development (e.g., first words did not appear until after the age of 2 years) as well as ongoing difficulty with one or more aspects of language, including comprehension and expression of complex syntax, semantics, or pragmatics. Phonological processing might also be affected. Signs and symptoms can be mild or severe and include deficits in one or more of the following areas:

Semantics (vocabulary): Poor word retrieval, frequent use of filler words (e.g., um, like), use of nonspecific words (e.g., thing, stuff), overall low vocabulary level (limited breadth as well as depth), difficulty understanding and learning new words and concepts, and difficulty understanding abstract concepts, including idioms and jokes(6,7,51)

Syntax (grammar): Difficulty understanding and using oral and written complex syntax, difficulty understanding and forming questions, and difficulty expressing ideas clearly using correct grammatical forms(4,6)

Pragmatics (social discourse): Difficulty retelling past events, difficulty understanding or telling narratives, and difficulty using language to socially engage (e.g., talks at length without regard for the listener's interest)(6,8)

Reading/writing/academics: LI in adolescents is associated with lower overall academic achievement.(65) Difficulty reading and comprehending material, difficulty with spelling and writing, difficulty understanding the details of a classroom lecture, and difficulty following classroom instructions.(6) Upper elementary school–aged  children and adolescents with LI have increased risk of difficulty with the language of math problems as well as nonlinguistic exact mathematic calculation (while general approximation or magnitude comparison is unaffected)(52,55)
Speech/articulation: The school-aged  child with a LI might also have difficulties producing specific speech sounds(9) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Vision and hearing loss should be identified or ruled out before a speech-language evaluation

The SLP should always consider the language that the child speaks at home when evaluating language ability. For detailed information on evaluating bilingual school-aged  children, please see Clinical Review…Language Disorders: Bilingual School-Aged  Children ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709066

causes: There is no single identified cause of LI as a primary disability. For Risk factors , see below
pathogenesis: Symptoms of a developmental LI typically appear within the first 2 to 3 years of life. The child often has had normaldevelopment in all areas but began talking late or had difficulties learning to talk and difficulties understanding complexlanguage.(10) The child might have also had immature speech-sound  production during the preschool years(10)–In a study conducted in the United Kingdom comparing language abilities in typically developing children (n = 38) tothose of children with LI (n = 13), researchers found atypical trajectories of phonological development in the childrenwith LI. Additionally, the relationship between lexical and phonological knowledge in children with LI was abnormalcompared to that of the typically developing children. Researchers hypothesized that these abnormalities likely contributeto LI because children with LI might have more difficulty abstracting phonological knowledge from lexical knowledge,might have more difficulty learning new words because of abnormal phonological knowledge, or might only be capableof reaching an immature stage of language development because of the limited phonological knowledge(48)–In a study conducted in the United States with 41 Russian-speaking  children (in 18 of whom LI was diagnosed),researchers found that despite intact representational syntactic knowledge, processing capacity limitations resulted inon-line  impairments of grammatical construction in the children with LI. Additionally, some of the language deficitsobserved appeared to be related to deficits of phonological short-term  memory capacity(49)–In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 22 children (ages 8 to 12) with SLI, researchers compared acousticperception abilities between the children with SLI and typically developing, age-matched  peers. Results indicated that,compared to the typically developing children, children with SLI exhibited reduced perception of two of the four acoustictasks: rise time and duration. Additionally, children with SLI exhibited reduced ability to perceive lexical stress patternsas compared to the typically developing children(57)

Authors of a meta-analysis  examined published and unpublished research on statistical learning abilities in persons withSLI compared to persons without SLI. Statistical learning is the manner in which typically developing children learnlanguage. Statistical learning occurs as listeners unconsciously hear and recognize patterns (statistical regularities) ofsyntax, morphology, and phonology. The authors of this meta-analysis  reported that research indicates that persons withSLI appear to have a deficit in statistical learning compared to persons without SLI, which might contribute to difficultylearning and using verbal language(60)
risk factors: High birth order (children who are born third or later)(12,61)

overall contraindications precautions: The speech-language  pathologist (SLP) needs to be aware of cultural considerations when assessing communicative functioning and when developing treatment goals. Language and literacy needs of the child should be considered with respect to the cultural, familial, and community setting

contraindications precautions to examina: Vision and hearing loss should be identified or ruled out before a speech-language evaluation

The SLP should always consider the language that the child speaks at home when evaluating language ability. For detailed information on evaluating bilingual school-aged  children, please see Clinical Review…Language Disorders: Bilingual School-Aged  Children ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709066

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when speech or language difficulties were first noticed. Who referred the child for an evaluation?

course of treatment.medical management: Determine whether the child is receiving medical care
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Diagnostic tests might include:
Psychological testing for cognitive ability (by a psychologist or educational psychologist)
Speech and language testing. For more information on specific tests, see Relevant tests and measures , below
Audiological testing to identify or rule out hearing loss
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies and whether they help. Do the parents assist with homework or with reading? Does the child have a tutor or other help outside of school?
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether child has had speech therapy or other intervention for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Does the child have hearing or vision difficulties?  -Does the child have a history of ear infections? -Does the child have behavior difficulties? -Does the child have difficulty in school? -Does the child exhibit articulation (speech) errors? -How are the child's social relationships? Does the child have good friends?
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -Was the child delayed in speaking? -Does the child have difficulty finding the right words? -Does the child have difficulty relating past events, telling stories, or explaining? -Does the child have frequent mispronunciations or difficulty with word retrieval or need extra time to provide an oral response?(14) -Does the child frequently misunderstand when spoken to? -Does the child use simplified grammatical structures or make grammatical errors? -Does the child have difficulty paying attention when spoken to? -Does the child have difficulty in conversations (e.g., is unaware of the listener's interest and monopolizes conversation)?
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Does the child experience greater language difficulties in certain situations? (e.g., with unfamiliar persons, in certain classes, when discussing certain topics)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Does the child have sleep difficulties that affect school performance?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the child may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician or social worker (e.g., behavior difficulties, seizures, attention problems, difficulty sleeping)Adolescents with LI have lower performance on measures of social skills and social cognitive abilities than typically developing adolescents.(15) Some have difficulty with emotional and behavioral self-regulation and are at risk for antisocial conduct disorders.(8) They are also at risk for having poorer quality friendships and for being bullied or victimized(15) -In a longitudinal study in the United Kingdom, researchers followed 65 students identified as having SLI from the age of 8 to 17 years.(16) Researchers investigated behavior, language, literacy, and self-concepts  at ages 8, 10, 12, 16, and 17 to determine whether early self-concepts  as well as behavioral, emotional, social, language, and literacy difficulties predicted behavioral difficulties and self-concepts  at 16/17 years of age. Results indicated that early language ability did not predict later behavioral difficulties or self-concepts.  However, researchers found that the correlation between academic self-concept  and reading accuracy level at 10 years approached significance. Researchers hypothesized that academic, rather than oral language, ability is the main factor linked to behavioral difficulties among adolescentsDoes the child have a history of ear infections? Has the child had a recent hearing evaluation? Does the child have difficulties with sound localization or auditory discrimination, or have difficulty understanding despite having normal hearing? Refer to an audiologist for a hearing evaluation or auditory processing evaluation as needed. For detailed information on language difficulties associated with central auditory processing disorder (CAPD), please see ClinicalT708565 -Authors of a study conducted in the United States with 782 adolescents from a juvenile detention center reported high rates of language disorders as well as low performance on tests of dichotic listening consistent with auditory processing deficits(62) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note history of respiratory problems as indicated

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of developmental delay in any area? Is there a history of hearing loss or ear infections?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask child or child’s family about other problems, including ADHD, depression, and anxiety
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask child or child’s family about other symptoms the child is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Things to consider include receive intervention services? If so, are they home, school, or clinic based?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -Obtain information on adaptive behaviors (as needed) and any adaptive equipment the child is using for communication or reading, including text-to-speech  software -Document the use of any assistive equipment for ADLs or mobility (e.g., wheelchair)
social and occupational history.living environment: What language(s) are spoken in the home? Does the child speak one language better than another? Does the child prefer one language to another?

relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading)If there are concerns about speech/articulation ability, a standardized test or an informal (nonstandardized) analysis can be used to determine errors that have a high frequency of occurrence. For specific sounds, the number of omissions, substitutions, distortions, and additions can be completedLanguage assessment should include a combination of formal and informal measuresThe following are examples of standardized language evaluations for upper elementary(17) A norm-referenced comprehensive language test (expressive and receptive language) for ages 5 years to 16 years, 11 months(18) A norm-referenced  comprehensive language test (expressive and receptive language) for ages 8 years to 12 years, 11 months(19) A standardized measure of receptive vocabulary for ages 2 years, 6 months to 90+ years(20) A norm-referenced  test of narrative comprehension and oral narration for ages 5 years to 11 years, 11 months(21) A individually administered, norm-referenced  test designed to assess listening comprehension and oral expression for ages 3 to 21 years(22) A norm-referenced, individually administered expressive and receptive language assessment for ages 3 to 21 years. Contains a subtest to measure pragmatic language skillsInformal language measures are ecologically valid examples of the child's language that can complement information from standardized tests and can include interviews with child, parents, and/or teachers about language difficulties, narrative samples, conversational samples, and expository discourse. Expository discourse samples (discourse that informs, explains, or describes) have been found to yield more group differences between adolescents with LI and those without LI than conversational samples.(23) The SLP might wish to employ an expository -Observations of the student in the classroom or lunchroom can be informative for pragmatic language assessment (23) -"Why do you like that game/sport?" -"I'm not familiar with that game/sport. Tell me about it. What are the rules, objectives, number of players, and so on?" -"What are some strategies to win the game/sport? How can you become a good player?"(24) -Place four envelopes containing a wordless picture book on a table. The envelopes can all contain the same wordless picture book (e.g., Frog Where Are You?  Mayer, 1969; What Next, Baby Bear?  Murphy, 1983; Pancakes for Breakfast , dePaola, 1978; A Boy, a Dog, and a Frog , Mayer, 1967) -Tell the student that all four envelopes contain a different story. Have the student to choose one envelope, look carefully at the story for a few minutes, and then come back and tell the story. The examiner has to "guess" which story it is"Now tell me the story of what happened in the book. Remember to tell me exactly all of the details so that I‘Once upon a time…’" -Some children and adolescents with LI are able to tell oral narratives but struggle with written narratives.(25) Take a written sample narrative"Can you tell me some of the things this person does that annoy you?"(24) This narrative topic can illuminate any grammatical errors and is more aligned with the everyday language of a teenager than a story narrative(24) -Language samples (50–100  utterances minimum for a full sample; shorter utterances to measure targeted skills) can be recorded and then analyzed for vocabulary, syntax, and pragmatic skills. Syntactic measures include mean length of terminable units (T-units)  (syntactic structures that include a main clause with all subordinate clauses), subordinate clause production, clausal density (average number of clauses per T-unit),  and syntactic errors. Analysis -Systematic Analysis of Language Transcripts (SALT)(26) -The Computerized Language Analysis (CLAN), available for free from the Child Language Data Exchange System//talkbank.org/manuals/CLAN.pdfProvide a fluency evaluation if there are concerns about a fluency disorder. For detailed information on childhood-onset  fluency disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicAccording to American Speech-Language-Hearing Association (ASHA) clinical practice guidelines, it is appropriate for an SLP to evaluate for and treat reading and writing impairment.(50) The rationale for SLPs to be involved in the development of literacy for children and adolescents is based on the connections between spoken and(a) spoken language lays the foundation for reading and writing; (b) spoken and written language are interdependent in that each builds on the other to create language and literacy competence throughout the lifespan; (c) children with spoken language deficits often experience difficulty learning to read and write; and (d) intervention for spoken language often results in improvements in written language abilities and vice versa(50) -Children with LI often have difficulty reading and writing. Assess reading and writing ability as necessary and age appropriate. The components of the reading evaluation will depend on the age of the child and his or her developmental level. These components include letter identification, letter-sound  identification, phonological awareness skills, sight word reading, fluency, and reading comprehension.(50) Written language tasks might include a written narrative -In a study in the United States designed to examine the use of abstract nouns and metacognitive verbs in a narrative writing sample of school-aged children and adolescents, researchers asked participants to “write a story about something funny, sad, or scary that happened to you and a friend.”(27) Researchers found that participants were engaged with this task and were reluctant to stop after the allotted 20 minutes. Narratives were analyzed with respect to total T-units,  mean length of T-unit,  clausal density, use of abstract nouns, and metacognitive verbs. Researchers concluded that this writing task was effective in eliciting literate words and complex syntax
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Assess the child’s oral motor skills during speech, imitation of motor movements, diadochokinesis tasks, and strength testing tasks in order to identify or rule out a motor-based speech-language disorderProvide a voice evaluation if there are concerns about a voice disorder
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Has the child received cognitive testing by a psychologist or psychiatrist? Document results of any cognitive evaluation –Authors of a meta-analysis  that included 131 studies comparing nonverbal cognitive test scores of children with SLI to those of typically developing children reported that children with SLI, on average, scored almost three quarters of a standard deviation below the typically developing children.(56) There was considerable variation across the research studies in terms of nonverbal cognitive tests used; when researchers controlled for the different tests, the effect size dropped slightly, from –0.72  to –0.69,  but both of these were significant differences.(56) Because diagnostic criteria for SLI include “normal nonverbal intelligence,” authors of this meta-analysis  caution against the use of traditional nonverbal cognitive testing for this population as it might not be appropriate for children with SLI or accurately reflect nonverbal abilities

other: Adolescents with poor language and literacy skills are at risk for personal, social, and economic disadvantage(28)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: A comprehensive language evaluation will determine the need for treatment and treatment goals
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Hearing loss English language learning difficulties Vision difficulties
prognosis: Prognosis for typical language development in a child with an LI varies according to multiple factors such as family support, coexisting diagnoses, cognitive abilities, motivation for therapy, and access to speech-language  therapy and home-based  language programs

Good metacognitive awareness (awareness of one’s own thought processes and learning strategies) is a good prognostic indicator for adolescents with SLI who undergo speech therapy for language disorders(63)
Children and adolescents with LI are at high risk for having reading difficulties(2,66)

When compared to typically developing peers, adolescents with LI have been found to be less independent (e.g., self-care activities, traveling, meeting people, managing finances), have poorer quality friendships, have difficulty with emotional and behavioral self-regulation,  and to be at higher risk for being bullied(8,15,28,29)

In a study conducted in the United Kingdom investigating educational outcomes for adolescents with LI, researchers found varying levels of performance on national educational examinations in secondary school. Higher IQ and stronger literacy skills were associated with higher academic achievement(30)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to a behavioral psychologist or behavioral specialist may be warranted to assist with behavioral therapy and/or challenging behaviors
treatment summary: Although individual educational plans (IEPs) focus on the educational needs of the individual student, parents/caregivers and the student have legal rights allowing them to be involved in the assessment, treatment planning, and therapy stages of service delivery. Parents should be considered and treated as integral parts of the IEP team(9)

The overall goal of language therapy for a child with a developmental LI should be to strengthen the child’s underlying semantic and lexical network, building stronger associative links in the real world to reduce word-finding  difficulties associated with LI(54)

Authors of a systematic review of vocabulary interventions for adolescents with LI published in 2018 found that the strongest evidence for effectiveness existed for approaches that combined phonological and semantic interventions. Overall, the research found that all models of delivery had the potential to be beneficial (e.g., 1:1 therapy sessions, small-group  sessions, and classroom-based  interventions). The review included 13 studies that met the inclusion criteria with participants aged 11 to 16 years, 11 months(58)

Language therapy can be school-  or clinic-based.  Several service-delivery  models are used to deliver language intervention in the U.S. public school system: individual therapy, small-group  therapy, collaboration with the teacher to deliver intervention within the classroom, and consultation with the teacher or teacher-aide to assist in delivering language intervention. There is no evidence to support one method over another; however, it is recognized that language goals should be linked to the curriculum when possible to provide multiple exposures to targeted language concepts (e.g., teaching vocabulary that is specific to content area classes)(4) –Response to Intervention (RTI): The RTI approach is a multitiered framework that involves universal screening to identify students who are at risk for language and reading difficulties, systematic evidence-based  classroom instruction, ongoing progress monitoring, and implementation of effective interventions for students who require more intensive instruction.(31) The first level (Tier 1) of the model involves providing high-quality,  evidence-based  instruction in a general education classroom. All students are screened at the beginning of the school year with a criterion-referenced  or norm-referenced  instrument to determine which students might benefit from additional instruction (e.g., students who fall below the 25th percentile on a screening measure). The second stage of the model (Tier 2) consists of small-group instruction and is directed toward students who continue to have difficulties despite the high-quality intervention. Their responsiveness to more intensive intervention is monitored after relatively short periods of time (e.g., 8 weeks). Tier 3  is provided for students who respond minimally to the second tier intervention and require specialized, more intensive instruction. When students fail to respond or respond minimally to the most intensive tier of instruction (Tier 3), they receive a comprehensive evaluation to determine their eligibility for special education services(31) -Cited advantages of the RTI approach include identification of students with language difficulties before they experience extensive academic failure, decreased numbers of students placed in special education, increased accountability for student performance in general and special education, reduced number of comprehensive evaluations, and increased time for collaboration among school professionals(32) -Studies investigating the effectiveness of the RTI approach in the upper elementary grades are limited(33,34) -SLPs often work in collaboration with general and special education teachers within an RTI model in roles such as the following: -Soliciting referrals from social studies and English teachers for students who would benefit from more intensive language instruction(35) -Providing direct service to students who need intensive language instruction. This instruction should be aligned with the curriculum(35) -Collaborating with school professionals to design interventions to improve Tier 1 instruction (e.g., suggest ways that a teacher can provide sufficient exposures to new vocabulary words for students)(36) -Collaborating with teachers to make modifications to the curriculum and instruction(35) -Administering progress-monitoring  measures to determine if the children are meeting benchmarks and to identify those who need additional instruction(36) -For detailed information on RTI, see Clinical Review…Response to Intervention (RTI) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709175

Collaborative teacher/SLP intervention –In an RCT in Australia, researchers investigated the efficacy of a collaborative intervention in which SLPs trained mainstream secondary teachers to make modifications in their oral and written language instruction.(37) A cohort of 13 teachers in two secondary schools (7 trained and 6 control) and 43 year-8  students (21 trained and 22 control) were tested preintervention, postintervention, and follow-up  3 months’ postintervention. Dependent measures included observations of the teachers’ use of techniques as well as student assessments in spoken and written language (Wechsler Individual Achievement Test-II  subtests of Listening Comprehension, Reading Comprehension, Written Expression, and Oral Expression). Teacher training was delivered in 10 50-minute  sessions over a period of 10 weeks in small-group  interactive meetings. Language modification techniques included: -teachers’ written language: Teachers were taught to break down large amounts of information on worksheets into smaller, visually distinct sections. They added graphics and visual icons as well as descriptions of instructional vocabulary -teachers’ oral language: Teachers were taught to make instructions explicit rather than implied and allow time for students’ processing and verbal responses. They repeated and paraphrased key instructions and faced the class when giving important information -information processing: Teachers were taught to include the whole class in deconstructing complex texts (e.g., creating mind maps on the board). They involved the whole class in creating visual aids to assist in information retention -direct vocabulary instruction: V ocabulary associated with each curricular topic was prioritized and vocabulary instruction was embedded in students’ learning through activities such as the use of visual symbols and whole-class interactive morphemic analysis –Results indicated a significant increase in the use of language modification techniques by trained teachers at postintervention and follow-up  and significant improvement in treatment group students’ written expression and listening comprehension relative to the control group immediately after intervention. No effects were found for oral expression and reading comprehension and no significant differences were found between treatment and control group at follow-up. Researchers hypothesize that adolescent students with LI may require additional support to achieve long-term  gains

Clinician/teacher directed methods of language intervention –Intervention for syntax and morphology difficulties: -Authors of a systematic review of language interventions for school-aged children (kindergarten–12th  grade) concluded that there is insufficient evidence to draw firm conclusions regarding therapy targeted at syntax difficulties. Only one study reviewed investigated intervention for upper grade children or adolescents, and it did not yield significant differences between the control and treatment groups.(4) Recommendations for intervention for syntax and morphology  are based on clinical guidelines presented in case studies and descriptive studies. Grammar instruction should be linked to the curriculum -Select syntactical constructions from the text to target and have the student brainstorm syntactic variations and meanings -Explicitly teach 5–10  examples of a specific syntactic construction. Encourage the student to self-generate examples(38) -Show the student how to maintain a list of grammar rules in a notebook(38) -Have the student use specific syntactic forms while answering questions about a text(38) -Explicitly teach commonly used prefixes and suffixes -Authors of a qualitative review of interventions for older students with syntax difficulties outlined 4 principles of instruction in helping students to understand and use the unique grammar of expository texts:(39) -Grammatical instruction and explicit manipulation of grammatical forms should be embedded within the context of the expository discourse task (reading of curriculum materials) as well as in isolated, decontextualized metalinguistic activities -Opportunities for practice of new grammatical forms should be provided in all modalities: reading, writing, and oral language -Students should have multiple exposure to target patterns as well as repeated opportunities to practice new grammatical forms -Materials for treatment should be drawn from students’ curricular materials -In a study conducted in the United States with 30 children with SLI ages 10 to 14 years, 11 months, researchers investigated the effects of once-weekly therapy (n = 14) compared to twice-weekly  therapy (n = 16) for 9 weeks. All treatment sessions were 40–60  minutes long and treatment focused on training the children to comprehend complex sentence structures using repetition, metalinguistic training, and guided practice. Outcome measures indicated that 80% of participants exhibited medium or large effect sizes in their ability to produce complex sentences in structured contexts. There was no significant difference in treatment gains noted between the participants who had therapy once weekly versus twice weekly(59) –Intervention for semantics/vocabulary deficits: Authors of a review of language intervention studies for school-aged children in kindergarten through 12th grade reported that there is a lack of strong evidence regarding the effectiveness of vocabulary interventions but that SLPs should have some confidence in interventions that involve collaborating with classroom teachers to provide systematic vocabulary instruction.(4) V ocabulary intervention in the later grades should always be aligned with content classes. To understand increasingly difficult expository texts (texts that provide information), students have to learn specific words associated with social studies, science, mathematics, and literature(38) -Provide a rich context for students to learn new words. New vocabulary should not be encountered in isolation but in contexts that enforce the words’ meaning, such as expository texts, visuals, and video clips -Collaborate with regular and special education teachers to design instruction to provide students with multiple exposures to new words. Students need opportunities to hear a new word, read it, and use it in speaking and writing. Computerized instruction can also be used to reinforce vocabulary concepts -Use semantic organizers (visual representations of how words are related to each other) to teach clusters of words and to assist students in forming links between words -Teach students independent word-learning  strategies so that they can find meanings of words they encounter in spoken or written language on their own -Introduce examples of new words to assist students in understanding the boundaries of the definition -Teach students to define words themselves. Students may work in pairs to infer the meaning of new words they encounter in texts. Begin with instruction on how to define concrete nouns and gradually move to more abstract nouns(40) -In an RCT in the United Kingdom, researchers investigated the effects of semantic therapy for word-finding  difficulties in 15 children aged 9 years, 11 months to 15 years, 11 months with persistent language impairments.(41) Participants were randomly assigned to a therapy vs. a delayed control group. Therapy involved two 15-minute  semantic therapy sessions per week for 8 weeks that targeted words from one of three semantic categories (animals, food, clothes). Activities included sorting pictures by semantic categories, discussing the semantic attributes of pictures, comparing pictures in terms of the attributes, and using these attributes and categories as cues in games (e.g., 20 questions). Dependent measures were the Test of Adolescent Word Finding (TAWF) and the Test of Word Finding in Discourse  (TWFD). Results indicated that both treatment groups had significant increases in scores on the TAWF after therapy that were maintained 5 months later; the control group did not have an increase on the TAWF. Neither group made significant gains on the TWFD -In a study in the United Kingdom, researchers investigated the relative effects of a vocabulary intervention and a narrative intervention on the language and reading abilities of 54 adolescents (mean age 12 years, 8 months) with severe and complex difficulties in language and communication.(42) Participants were randomly assigned to a vocabulary intervention group or a narrative intervention group. Each group received intervention in two 50-minute  sessions per week for 6 weeks -Narrative intervention: Targeted the understanding and telling of stories with a focus on story structure, story description, and inferential understanding -V ocabulary intervention: Key concepts of vocabulary were taught through mind-mapping,  word associations, and word building. Specific concepts from the National Curriculum were targeted -Pretest language and reading measures indicated no significant difference between the two treatment groups. At posttest, both groups showed significant improvements on measures of receptive vocabulary, recalling sentences, and nonliteral comprehension. Differences between groups on other measures did not reach significance(42) –Interventions for pragmatic deficits: Authors of a systematic review of language interventions for school-aged  children in kindergarten through 12th grade did not identify any intervention studies for pragmatic deficits of children in the upper grades.(4) Pragmatic targets might include telling narratives, describing past events, asking questions, requesting help, interpreting people's emotions, taking another's perspective, maintaining topic, monitoring one's own conversational contributions, and interacting with peers. Activities to address these targets might include:(43) -Stories can be used to discuss the characters' actions and intentions to target specific social discourse goals -Story structure can be illustrated by examples as well as explicit instruction on narrative components (e.g., introduction, setting, characters). Cue cards with the components can be used to prompt children as they tell or retell narratives -Video of social interactions can be used to discuss and evaluate others' social discourse -Role-plays  can be used to practice social discourse goals -Multiple opportunities should be provided to use behaviors in different contexts to allow for generalization –Intervention for receptive language/auditory comprehension -In a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 72 children ages 9 to 17 years, researchers investigated the effectiveness of individual therapy sessions targeting individualized receptive and expressive language deficits (as well as some articulation and phonological awareness deficits). Researchers selected targets as well as control measures and found significant improvement on the targets after intervention (30% improvement on targets versus 8% improvement on controls). Researchers concluded that individualized, individual speech therapy for older children with SLI is effective(64) -In an RCT conducted in the United Kingdom with 14 adolescents with severe receptive LI, researchers reported significant gains in comprehension of coordinating conjunctions after 4 hours of individual shape coding therapy(53) -In Phase 1 of the trial, the therapy group received eight 30-minute individual sessions of shape coding therapy (explicit teaching with visual support) along with their usual speech therapy sessions. In Phase 2, the waiting control group received the same therapy protocol(53) -Therapy sessions consisted of introduction to coordinating conjunctions and explicit teaching of their meaning through spoken explanations and visual supports (i.e., the subject is circled, the auxiliary has a diamond written around it, the verb phrase is marked with a hexagon, and the adjective phrase has a cloud drawn around it)(53) -Coordinating conjunctions were introduced one at a time in a variety of sentences, and each step built on the previous step; the SLP did not move on to the next target conjunction until good comprehension was achieved (exact percentage of accuracy was not reported)(53) -At the conclusion of the 4 hours of individual therapy, subjects’ language skills were reassessed; significant improvement in comprehension of coordinating conjunctions was observed for the therapy group as compared to the waiting controls. After the waiting control group completed the therapy, their scores were significantly higher as well. Additionally, researchers combined results of phase 1 and 2 and found a significant effect overall. These gains were maintained at a 4-month  follow-up  as well(53) –Interventions for comprehension/text comprehension: Comprehension instruction in the later grades usually is associated with comprehension of specific texts. The following are techniques to assist students with comprehension in content area classes:  -Activate the student's prior knowledge: Discuss the text with the student prior to reading it to elicit background knowledge about the subject matter. Students can also be guided to read previews, summaries, or section headings before reading the text(38) -Assist the student to engage in active learning: Instruct the student how to use different materials such as quizzes, notes, alternative texts, personal summaries, or online resources to reinforce knowledge. Students with LI do not always study in an efficient way and need to be taught a script for reviewing material(38) -Target useful vocabulary: Target words for the student to learn should be identified in the text. The student can practice using vocabulary by answering questions about the text, retelling parts of the text using target words, making definitions with the words, or using target words in sentence generation. See above for more information on vocabulary instruction(38) -Facilitate strategy use: The SLP can assist the student in using different comprehension strategies. The following are some strategies that the student can use while reading text. All strategies should be explicitly taught and modeled by the SLP or teacher:(44,45,46) -Graphic and semantic organizers: Readers make visual or graphic representations of what they read -Question answering: The teacher/SLP poses questions before, during, or after reading -Question generation: Students are taught to ask themselves questions about what they read -Story structure: Students are taught to use story mapping to help them recall the details and parts of a story -Summarization: After reading a text, students are asked to summarize (orally or by writing) what they have just read

Computer-based  intervention/training in rapid auditory processing: Fast ForWord (FFW) is a computer program designed to improve a child's detection of rapidly presented and changing speech stimuli. The program is based on the hypothesis that children's reading and language deficits are due to a general auditory processing deficit(47) –The effectiveness of FFW for improving reading and language abilities for 2nd-and 7th-grade  students at risk for language and reading difficulties was examined in an RCT conducted in 8 schools (N = 274 7th-grade  students) in the United States.(47) Participants in the treatment group received supplemental instruction with FFW (100 min/day, 5 days a week for 4 to 8 weeks). The control group received no additional intervention. The 7th-grade  students used a middle school version of the software that had graphics and content tailored to their age and grade levels. The authors concluded that FFW did not help the students improve their language and reading comprehension scores on a standardized achievement test . maintenance or prevention: The child's progress on language goals should be monitored regularly to make appropriate adjustments in therapy

There is some evidence that breastfeeding directly after birth has a protective effect against SLI. Researchers in the Netherlands theorized that this might be related to the fact that children who breastfeed have a lower rate of ear infections, might be because breastfeeding involves increased communication between mother and child, or possibly is a result of the nutritional benefits of breastmilk for brain development(61) Patient/Family Education
